cab.content: Printed for the War Cabinet. March 1940.SECRET.W.P. (G.) (40) 89.March 26, 1940.ToTDER LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET.NO SEPARATE PEACE.Memorandum by the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.IN view of the forthcoming meeting of the Supreme War Council I circulate,herewith, to my colleagues the draft of the proposed Anglo-French declarationnot to conclude a separate peace and concerning post-war co-operation, which formed the subject of my paper W.P. (G.) (40) 86 and was discussed by the WarCabinet on the 21st March.My colleagues will observe that the second paragraph of the declaration hasbeen expanded to cover foreign policy. The Lord Privy Seal has suggested thatcolonial policy should also be included.I should be grateful if a decision could now be taken on the terms of thedraft declaration to be submitted to the French representatives on the 28th March.H.Foreign Office, March 26, 1940._Draft Declaration.THE undersigned, duly authorised thereto by their respective Governments,hereby declare as follows : (1) The Government of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and NorthernIreland and the Government of the French Republic, being equallydetermined to carry on the war with the utmost vigour until thepurposes for which it was undertaken are attained, mutuallyundertake that during the present war they will neither negotiatenor conclude an armistice or treaty of peace, except by mutual agreement.(2) The two Governments further declare their intention to continue the closest co-operation in their financial, economic, defence and foreignpolicy after the conclusion of peace.copy no. 1310946 [21035]
